Yes, there were a few controversies surrounding John Wesley's works during his lifetime. One of the most significant controversies arose when he began to preach and write about the doctrine of "Christian perfection." This doctrine teaches that it is possible for believers to reach a state of "perfect love" and, as a result, to be free from sin. Some of Wesley's critics accused him of promoting a form of human perfectionism that was incompatible with traditional Christian teachings about the nature of sin and redemption.

Another controversy surrounding Wesley's works was his critique of the Anglican Church and its practices. He was a strong advocate for the importance of personal religious experience and often criticized the Church for relying too heavily on dogma and rituals. Some within the Church accused him of promoting ideas that were inconsistent with Anglican theology and suggested that he was seeking to create a separate, dissenting Church.

Despite these controversies, Wesley's writings were widely read and had a significant impact on the development of Methodism as a distinct religious movement. His emphasis on personal experience, social outreach, and the importance of religious education continues to influence Christians to this day.
